) An objective evaluation of whether to recommend appeal is imperative. The Office of Chief Counsel must balance a variety of considerations in deciding whether to recommend appeal. Appeals often take many months, and the results are often unpredictable. An error of fact, law or analysis, standing alone, does not necessarily merit an appeal recommendation. The Office of Chief Counsel should recommend appeal only as part of an overall strategy support Service position and sound tax administration. (

) The legal correctness or incorrectness of the lower court decision is the primary basis for determining whether to recommend appeal. Attorneys carefully consider the opinion of the lower court with an open mind. If persuaded by the court’s rationale, the attorney should recommend cence or other change in Service position. (

) Consider the administrative importance, whether national or local, and a discussion in the appeal letter. Administrative considerations may include potential revenue impact of the adverse decision, and the number of the decision may affect. The Service may have information that will assist this factor. (
) Consider the record on appeal, e.g., is the Government’s position set out clearly and supported by competent testimony and documentary evidence, the correct argument made? (

) Weigh the equities of the case. Cases involving taxpayers who appear in a sympathetic light or where the Service’s actions are called into question not present the best vehicles for obtaining favorable precedent on important legal issues. (

) Consider whether the Government will derive any pecuniary benefit if the adverse decision is reversed. For example, in a bankruptcy case, consider whether the Government can expect to be paid given the financial condition the bankruptcy estate. Even if the Government may derive no pecuniary benefit, consider whether the decision will adversely affect collection in cases. A case involving no pecuniary benefit to the Government rarely will appealed. (
) In collection cases, consider whether there are other sources of collection may be available apart from the source of collection precluded by the decision. (

) The nature and contents of an appeal letter depend upon whether the are of a legal or factual nature and the court making the decision. An letter must always be written in light of the standard of review applicable to case and should be focused on the issues relevant to the appeal. (

) A letter recommending a petition for rehearing en banc must be sent to the Department of Justice no later than

days after the court of appeals’ or order is filed or after receipt of the request from the Department of Justice. Since any letter recommending a petition for rehearing en banc must be reviewed and approved by various offices within the Office of Chief Counsel and by the Chief Counsel and General Counsel, Treasury, it is imperative that such letters be prepared expeditiously. (

) Considerations in recommending rehearing en banc. a. a. For rehearing en banc, as for other appellate purposes, controversy in tax cases is defined in terms of a decision against the Government and not a mere refusal to accept the Government’s legal theory. See CCDM

, Preparation of Appeal Letters. The letter to the Department of Justice should set forth very persuasive reasons why rehearing en banc should be sought. b. Rehearing en banc is generally recommended when either the panel decision conflicts with a decision of the United States Supreme Court or the court to which the petition is addressed or the proceeding involves or more questions of exceptional importance, and this should be clearly stated in the letter. c. In the absence of an intracircuit or Supreme Court conflict, en banc may nevertheless be recommended when the issue is one of exceptional administrative importance requiring prompt resolution. d. The exceptional administrative importance of the issue should be stated explicitly, and the intracircuit or Supreme Court conflict, if any, should be explained. e. The nationwide jurisdiction of the Federal Circuit is one factor in ing a recommendation for rehearing en banc. A loss in this circuit may mean that the Government will not litigate another case with the issue. (
